Ookami to Koushinryou (Spice and Wolf) short description:

Spice and Wolf is a Japanese light novel series written by Isuna Hasekura, with illustrations by Juu Ayakura. ASCII Media Works has published 20 novels since February 2006 under their Dengeki Bunko imprint. ASCII Media Works reported that as of October 2008, over 2.2 million copies of the first nine novels have been sold in Japan. The series has been called a "unique fantasy" by Mainichi Shimbun due to the plot focusing on economics, trade, and peddling rather than the typical staples of fantasy such as swords and magic. Yen Press licensed the light novels and is releasing them in English in North America. ASCII Media Works has published three volumes of a spin-off light novel series titled Wolf and Parchment since September 2016.


A manga adaptation illustrated by Keito Koume began serialization in the November 2007 issue of ASCII Media Works' seinen manga magazine Dengeki Maoh. The manga was licensed by Yen Press, which has begun releasing the volumes in English. A 12-episode anime adaptation aired between January and March 2008, plus a single original video animation (OVA) episode released in May 2008. A second OVA was released in April 2009 as a prequel to the second anime season Spice and Wolf II, which aired 12 episodes between July and September 2009. Both anime seasons were released in English by Kadokawa Pictures USA and Funimation. Two visual novels based on the series for the Nintendo DS were released by ASCII Media Works in June 2008 and September 2009.


Horo and Lawrence

«Spice and Wolf» focuses on the story of a wandering merchant named Kraft Lawrence. The story takes place in the medieval period, at the time when danger was awaiting you at every corner and turn: outlaws, different deadly illnesses, and church, which was the number 1 issue for many-- a misstep and you become a heretic. Kraft Lawrence has been wandering for 7 years already, trying to earn enough money to open his own shop and to become a better merchant. When he leaves another small village to sell goods, he finds the Goddess of harvest in his wagon. Horo explains the merchant that people no longer need her help and are starting to forget about her: they neither pray to her, nor do they even remember about her lending a helping hand to them when they needed it. And after a little test, the merchant agrees to take the Goddess on his journey. Because who would refuse to have a Goddess on your side? (Kraft, you lucky bastard)!


Characters

There are only two protagonists in the series--the wolf girl Goddess Horo and the merchant Kraft Lawrence. It becomes obvious right from their first meeting that they complement each other well, and this first impression will prove correct later on. Kraft Lawrence is calm, when Horo is quick-tempered, but they both care for each other. What I am trying to say is that both of them are very different, but they are also very similar to each other. And the reason for that is their loneliness, they both are aware of. As the series progresses, the protagonists will have to face many challenges that will test them. With that being said, I believe that with every new episode of Spice and Wolf, you might fall in love with this series more and more. 


Horo

Horo — is a local deity of harvest; her original form is a tremendous wolf. Several centuries ago, she came to the south from her homeland in the north. She agreed to protect the village’s harvest. However, humans are ungrateful creatures that are unable to understand that even a deity is unable to control nature. With time, soil becomes exhausted and is no longer able to support crops or other plant life. But the villagers think that this is just the Deity’s whim and blame her for everything, little by little forgetting about her existence. Having understood that people no longer need her help, Horo decides to return to her homeland. 


Aside from that, Horo has two forms: the first being a giant wolf and her second is a 15-year old girl. Horo is fond of delicious food and alcohol, but especially loves apples. She takes pride in her tail and takes special care of it, constantly combing and maintaining it.


Without a single doubt, Horo is one of the reasons for success of this series. She might be one of the most interesting and beautiful female characters you will ever see. It is somewhat challenging to give a proper description of her character, because she is always different. She is very smart, her jokes are better than what you see in 90% of comedy series, she looks strong, but she also makes an impression of a fragile creature that you want to protect really baldly. She is always ready to help; a perfect companion a merchant will ever find. 


Lawrence

Krawft is a merchant that hopes one day to open his own shop. At 12, he became a student of an experienced merchant; at 18 he started his journey to earn enough money to open his own shop. Since that time, he has been earning money for 7 years already, buying and selling goods in different towns. As a true merchant, he is trying to find profit in everting and refuses to accept unprofitable deals. When he meets Horo, he agrees to help her. Yet, in return, she will have to compensate for losses. Kraft Lawrence is very smart and crafty, but also very kind individual, which Horo dislikes about him. 


Although, there is nothing special about him, as a character, he makes a very positive impression. Mainly because of the fact that with story-line development, his character also changes. (Which is rare for some series). On top of that, you cannot say that Lawrence is weak: he is ready to stand up for those who are dear to him. Though, when the situation is dire, Horo will help him. That said, he is a very interesting character with his own principle and beliefs; his development is very interesting to follow. His cold, but also kind character complements Horo very well.


Plot

The plot consists of three main components: trade, action, and dialogues. Despite the fact that trade is often associated with something boring, in case of Spice and Wolf, the economics is presented in an easy-to-understand manner, and is explained in detail. This, as I think, makes the story-line even more interesting, but never boring. As a person who loves strategy games and especially everything connected with trade, I found elements of economics very interesting to follow. Although, many may disagree with me. Personally, I found it interesting to find out about many tricks that are connected with coining of money and how one can make a fortune using these tricks. Action scenes are the only drawback to find in Spice and Wolf; there are like two scenes in the whole 2 seasons. That said, if you are looking for some actions scenes, that is not the anime you should be looking for. But even without action scenes Spice and Wolf is able to prove that it is a masterpiece, a diamond, which is very difficult to find sometimes, because even without action, it is able to kindle your interest, which is a huge problem of many SoL series. 


Holo and Lawrence

The most important role in the story-line, based on the economics would surely play dialogues. It is not surprising, because Spice and Wolf is based on the light novel, which was written by Isuna Hasekura. And as you know, this means that there will be many dialogues, and the success of the series will only depend on the quality of these dialogues. I must say that, for some reason, they work well. I cannot describe the reason why they work that well: the reason for that might have been an excellent work of the Japanese voice actors that voiced Horo and Lawrence (by the way, I would highly recommend you to watch it in Japanese with English subtitles, or insert your first language subtitles. The amount of the work the Japanese voice actors paid to their characters is simply amazing, Spice and Wolf is one of these series you should only watch in Japanese. But, of course, it depends on your likes and dislikes, so feel free to watch it in whatever language you want), maybe because of the superb dialogues, written by Hasekura Isuna. Another thing worth mentioning is that these dialogues are never annoying, because they give you all the needed information. However, sometimes you will still have to think based on the information you have about some things that have not been mentioned in the series. 


Art

Without a doubt, the series is somewhat old. (The second season has a much better art than the first series, simply an eye candy, by the way). However, one thing is obvious-- the amount of work paid to make every single frame look amazingly beautiful. Not only do characters look unique, but also their outfits, backgrounds; the whole series look quite enjoyable, because it is somewhat a challenge to capture that medieval feel in your work. Spice and Wolf animators, however, did manage to do it. 


Music

Composed by Yuji Yoshino, a Japanese composer who has done a variety of works in video game music, such as in .hack//Legend of the Twilight. He has also arranged a number of music collections for the Suikoden series, including Genso Suikoden IV Music Collection: Another World, some tracks of Genso Suikoden Celtic Collection 2, and all of Genso Suikoden Celtic Collection III, Spice and Wolf’s OST is truly charming.


The opening performed by Natsumi Kiyoura perfectly illustrates how lonely both Horo and Kraft are. However, together they are not lonely anynore, they can overcome all the possible hardships they might face, and no matter how long their journey is going to be, they will still succeed. The ending theme displays the comedy part of the series and it is possible to say that it illustrates Kraft’s and Horo’s relationship. 


Grade:

Overall (dub) : c

Overall (sub) : A

Story : B+

Animation : B+

Art : A

Music : A+


All in all, Spice and Wolf is a series worth watching, but it requires some patience in order to fully appreciate the pacing and complexities in the plot and in order to engage with the characters. Fans of SoL will highly appreciate every single detail in Spice of Wolf; there is nothing I can dislike, or criticize in this series. My only regret is that it did not get a third season. But it should not worry you, since you can always find light novel’s spoilers on the internet.

If you watch this anime, be prepared tobe captivated by these two incredibly designed characters, and you'll be left hungering for more.

Ookami to Koushinryou is one of those shows that fall under the category of more complex/focused shows like Death note and Code Geass, where one really needs to focus on what is going on in a sense, in order to fully understand.  While personally, I could care less about that stuff due to my simple nature, I will say that I fully enjoyed this series to its fullest.
Story (9/10): Spice and wolf, as this series is known in English, has, on one hand a rather simple plot.  The actual 12 episode anime is split into 2 arcs, where each of them correspond toa different problem that the 2 main characters, Lawerence and Holo, must overcome.  The reason why I say this plot is simple is for one reason only; its exposition.  The exposition and the meeting of the 2 leads is very easy to understand and done very simply and beautifully.  The majority of this series is done in this simple concept, and executes it very well with an easygoing plot line and its wonderful, glorious, banter.  


On the other hand, Spice and wolf has another side to its simple traveling style, explained in the form of medieval economics.  Yes, the complicated part I was talking about at the beginning of this review, is reflected like this.  Because the series has a merchant for its main lead, the characters face economic situations and problems which...confuse me.  Personally, I hate it.  While watching it, I was always confused about what was going on when the economics part was occurring, to the point that I paused the show and read the subtitles, and still didn't get it.  The economics goes very deep, and to one who doesn't have any knowledge of economics, it can be a bit of a turn off.


Overall, the story of Spice and wolf definitely has a solid plot that isn't too difficult to understand, (minus the economics), and doesn't at all feel droned out or carried out.  It picks up when it wants to, and slows down when it needs to.  It didn't feel boring at all, and I enjoyed all of it.


Character (9/10):  I just want to get one thing straight.  I...Love...Holo.  The wolf deity of the north is by far, one of the best female leads in all of anime history.  The reasons for this is because of just how awesome and wonderful she is.  She's flirty, mischievous, smart, etc.  Overall, she's a very complex character that cannot be put under the normal troupes for female characters that we all know.  She's an individual character that stands out so much, that she is by far, one of my favorite characters of all time.  Adding to her complexity is the fact that she has a hidden side to her, that just makes her all the more awesome and adorable, not to mention, more realistic in terms of an actual person.  I just cannot put into words just how awesome of a character she is.  


The series's male counterpart, Lawrence is quite awesome in his own way.  As a traveling merchant, he has innate knowledge of economics and plays the part as the one who sets up the plot for the series.  I find however, that most of his character is defined with Holo.  It's because of her that we get to see more of Lawrence, developing his character more, and allowing us to see sides we've never seen before.  The series focuses on the relationship between these 2, which makes them so much better, and adds so much good quality and merit to it.


Side characters are arcic.  (I made that up.)  Meaning, similar to the word episodic, is that they all pertain to a certain arc.  Any character other than the main two, you will never see beyond the arc that they're in.  It's a bit strange that they just drop off of the face of the earth, but it's perfectly fine considering that they're not the main people that drive the story.  


Art and Sound (8/10 and 9/10):  The art for spice and wolf has a very rustic feel to it.  It features quite a bit of dull colors, reminiscing the olden european age of the renaissance age with wooden buildings, marketplaces, and oh so beautiful scenery.  The characters themselves are fairly simple in terms of clothing design, and fit very well with how this anime displays and shows itself.  The animation is very fluid, and overall, looks really nice.  It really sets itself apart from a large majority of animes, considering that the setting is in a completely diferent area.  Although, the animation can get a bit strange sometimes.  (there's a horse that derps around.  It was hilarious!)


The music.  Oh my god!!!  Personally, I think that Spice and wolf has one of the best soundtracks in anime history.  Its opening Tabi no Tochu is one of the most gorgeous things I have heard.  It's incredibly soft and soothing, with a bit of a depressed tone as well as some pick-ups, that works so well for this anime.  It fits incredibly well, and I love it.  Its ED is also very interesting and fun.  It's a short little song that contrasts its OP companion, with a fun little song that is sung in english.  It's very different and very fun to listen to as it has a very upbeat beat, and some pretty fun lyrics.  It's background music is awesome as well.  (To me, when background music in the anime sounds really good, you know the soundtrack is awesome.)  To compliment its medieval europe feel, the background tracks are split into 2 categories.  One, is a track with light and airy wind instruments for when the plot isn't serious, and a more string heavy song for when the anime picks up.  All in all, the music is gorgeous and I applaud the people who made and played them.  


The voice acting for both english and Japanese versions are wonderful as well.  Spice and wolf has a pretty good dubbed version of itself.  But personally, I would recommend the sub, only if either you're like me and prefer subs, or you really want to understand the economics of this anime.  Since it provides words that you read off over and over again when paused.  


Personal Enjoyment (9/10): While no, I'm not a big fan of economics, thus repeatedly getting confused with the whole financial situation, I found Spice and wolf to be a rather fun and good series to watch.  Spice and wolf hosted a pretty good and interesting plot, which I always love seeing, as well as how original it actually was compared to what we have these days.  There's a nice hint of romance which I can secretly ship, and overall, just wonderful, wonderful characters.  (Holo in particular.) I would highly recommend this show to anyone who would love an original and semi-serious plot line, filled with banter and golden conversations, and the occasional drunk goddess.  After watching this series, my only wish, is that I could have someone like Holo in my life.  Seriously, that would make life so much more interesting.  


Overall Score: 8.92


P.S.  Yes, I have watched the second season, and will write a review about it in the future.

SPICE AND WOLF REVIEW:
MINDSET:
Unique for Anime, but not so ambitious.
SYNOPSIS:
In 1*whatever the date is in Europe* AD comes a travelling merchant (peddler) known as Lawrence, who all of a sudden saw a beautiful wolf Godess in he's cart at one night called Holo. Holo then managed to persuade Lawrence into taking her in he's cart, so she can get to the North. The two set off a journey filled with Drama, excitement, Tension and best of all... *drum roll* beastiali- I mean the two just sitting down and talking all day.
REVIEW:
To be critical, I have re-watched some of the show for a bit of nostalgiaand the intense moments when Holo and Lawence being no longer together for a while has just lost its effect, since the tension has shorten into a predictable;e arch, any ways, the chemistry between the couple is so good that the show is probably going to hit sh*t ratings if they die too early. 


Holo and Lawrence are still one of the best romance couples I still know of to this day because Anime has this horrible tendency to make there couples either feel like one or two dimensional characters, or mass cloned from the Unholy Grail of 20th century Anime known as the Archetype Virus.


The chemistry (wait, thats quite an overused term when You describe couples in reviews, let me change it to get out of the cliché plague a bit....) the writers conjuring alchemy blending the duo can make some really entertaining reactions, it has in some way a depth of realism, and Holo and Lawrence just simply being themselves as a happy couple is the biggest strength of the show, both in casuals, new fans, veterans, replay-value and the age of time will be given a pass for this.


Yes I am a Holo fanboy, and Lawrence, though fairly on par just doesn’t seem to be Holo's more equal counter part (in terms of critical standards go)


The plot will not be as strong as it will it ever be, and side characters don't have a great deal of personality or exploration for us to care too much about them, and this is probably the biggest grype of the cast, Holo and Lawrence just easily out shines every character in terms of depth, personality, interactions, reactions, complexity and many other major factors. Sure, they are good side characters and some DEFINITLY, above average, however they do seem to have enough screen time to have nice grasp of there personality, though they seem to feel a bit too much like back drop at times.


I have a good feeling that Spice And Wolf, depsite how different it is to a lot of Romance Anime still has small signs of its Anime tropes (what do You expect something to be made in the 2000's?) like the Shepherd Girl who seems to just be this really kind person and seems to act in this near perfect manner, or how Lawrence's apprentice shows signs that she is in love with him.


Wait, Lawrence has Holo, Chloey and Norah... and all of them seem to at least show some level of love interest to him.... Hareeeeem anyooooone?


Plot conveniences are there, but they don't seem to go as far to be so distracting, like how Holo gets a new pair of clothes and how she always seems to get the best ones because 80% realosm ans 20% plot convenience, but such events don't seem to be annoying in any way shape or form.


Though season 2 seemed like the same thing, going near the end we all got p!ssed when I was about to give the show a higher score! To be honest, there was nothing much to talk about season 2 except for that badly written ending and that there closer to the North.


Somthing Spice and Wolf was infamous for was its use of describing economics instead of having Your boring History teacher, we have the Teachers animated! But, it does get tiring after listening a dragged out speech about economics that You soon forget about the next hour, fortunately, it does finally manage to fix that sort of pacing to be more tolerable soon enough.


Brains Base seem to do a very well detailed job on immersing with its very clear and beautiful backgrounds, You see a healthy amount of orange flames emitted as light, a sharp blend of CGI and 2-D feel for most of the backgrounds (especially the old housing and infrastructure) though its very tolerable as it looks rather beautiful and still stands with modern day standards. Holo looks absolutely beautiful and the rest of the other cast seem to look decent enough, though the girls seem to be tad flashy.


I watched the dub, and it feels like it has a mix between an American and British accent combined, You clearly cannot tell who is from this County of the UK and what kind of Englishman they are, but it still a damn great dub, each voice actor fits there voice amazingly, and  every sounds great. The music is mostly Folk with an upgrade, and has has this old European feel with its own modern twist from there compositions which is both unique and great! It also adds an accordion to the mix. The OP and ED songs are both great to listen to, and get You to the mood very nicely.


LEGACY:

I think the biggest all rounder for the series is something that I think many casuals have went into the misunderstanding that the show at its core is really just two travelling merchants as a couple stocking up on supplies each time they get closer to the North to find any living wolves happening to stay by. That alone is not some crazy and ambitious concept that will get a greatly high score if You know that the biggest strength is not the Drama and rising tension to a harsh climax, but one that seems to like the safer route a bit more has a sprinkle of its own harsh moments, but is not meant to make You cry or give You a heart attack. It is made to be a very calming, entertaining, joyful and overall not considerably great by from my definition. You see this show not to sob, or go f**king ape shat on a wet bra, but to just see to very entertaining pieces of chemicals reacting in a happy and cleverly sarcastic manner... Which is why giving a score of 9-10 is just silly!


SCORES:

6.5/10- Holo and Lawrence = Amazing Couple, side characters are above average at best, and that's all.

6/10- The plot likes to stay at the safety area, but for a peaceful road journey that just there for the atmosphere, well done.

7/10- Great Animation Brains Base!

7.5/10- Great folk tunes guys!

6.5/10- Entertainment value is 85% to Lawrence and Holo, and the 15% can be anything, which is not all rounding.


FINALE: 7/10!

Synopsis:
Kraft Lawrence, a traveling merchant looking for a beneficial trade to make, encounters a mysterious girl with the ears and tail of a wolf asleep in his cart. Later on, Lawrence finds out that that mysterious girl, Holo(Horo), is a harvest Goddess longing to return to her beloved homeland somewhere in northern lands, as she feels that the town has forgotten about her existence. The two make a deal leaving the village behind and start their new journey to the Horo’s birthplace.
-Story (10/10)-
Spice and Wolf (Ookami to Koushinryou) narrates a story about lonely traveling merchant, Kraft Lawrence, looking for a beneficial trade to make. Onone of his journeys to the Pasloe village he encounters a mysterious girl with the ears and tail of a wolf asleep in his cart. Later on, the story reveals that that mysterious girl is the harvest Goddess called Holo(Horo) longing to return to her beloved home, since the Pasloe people have forgotten about the solicitous Goddess. The two make a deal leaving the village behind and start their new journey towards happiness and disappointment.


Spice and Wolf is a medieval fantasy and one of these anime proving that a journey can actually be catching. Spice and Wolf’s storyline mostly revolves around the day-to-day travels of a wandering merchant and his fascinating companion, Horo. The main problem of such anime is that it becomes boring after the first 2 or 3 episodes. By the way, Spice and Wolf has 2 seasons(25episodes), an OVA and two special episodes. It is quite long, isn’t it? Here comes the question, why do people like it that much? The answer is simple, Spice and Wolf is called a masterpiece, because it is able to not only show you some relaxing scenes, but also make you worry, and believe me, Spice and Wolf WILL surely make you worry about a thing or two.


-Animation (10/10)-


While Spice and Wolf doesn’t have a brand new animation to brag about, it still has its advantages: the animation perfectly displays the medieval setting (from landscapes to the ancient cities encircled with walls.) In addition to this, the attention paid to the colors can’t left anyone unsurprised. Spice and Wolf’s colors are simply bewitching. The series’ cast, as well as their cloth, are also very beautiful to look at. 


-Sound (10/10)-


I appreciate both English and Japanese dubs. Alas, the quality of the English dubbed versions, in most cases, is far from being bearable. Spice and Wolf does have a bearable English cast; however, in the Japanese version the main characters are voiced by Fukuyama Jun(Lamperouge Lelouch, Lute Ryner, Okumura Yukio) and Koshimizu Ami(Stadtfeld Kallen, Matoi Ryuuko), who did one hell of a job voicing their characters. If you are familiar with these two, it may be a good idea to watch it in Japanese. 


The music was also very pleasant. Tabi no Tochuu by Kiyoura Natsumi and Ringo Biyori by ROCKY CHACK, will surely be added to your music list. Never annoying, both themes fit the anime well, not saying that the OST is splendid, as well.


-Characters (10/10)-



It is, indeed, a very important criterion for every adventure-based series and I must say that Spice and Wolf has managed not to fail that important task. It is truly a very difficult thing to do: to please both males and females and, somehow, this anime does it simply brilliant leaving absolutely no flaws. As stated in the synopsis, Spice and Wolf revolves around the two characters: Horo and Lawrence. 


Horo displays a dream of every man, she is the interpretation of beauty, she is fragile; yet, she is able to protect what is dear for her, she is wise, but sometimes she may make a mistake. It is truly captivating that Horo isn’t a human; nevertheless, she is the most humane creature you will ever find in this anime.


Kraft Lawrence is more a strategist than a person who can easily fight against a bunch of people barehanded. However, when it is time to fight, he is ready to fight even a battle that will be impossible to win. Kraft Lawrence is a person who lives for the others.


In result, both characters are lonely and don’t have a place to go to, but together they form a heartwarming duo, which will be surely interesting for both males and females, no matter how old you actually are.


-Enjoyment (10/10)-


I honestly can’t express my happiness, Spice and Wolf is one of these rare gems, which will leave a huge hole in your heart, as you, perhaps, will never find a show even a bit similar to what Spice and Wolf is.


The good:


1)Story-line.

2)Animation.

3)Characters.

4)Music.

5)Enjoyment.


The bad:


1)The anime adaptation is unfinished and the probability of S3 is almost zero. (For more information, please, read the overall part.)


-Overall (10/10)-


Spice and Wolf doesn’t have a brilliant story to offer to its viewers; yet, it, somehow, proves that even a plain adventure may become something you will never forget about. It is a gorgeous show with very likable characters. It is a very deep show, which talks on such topics as: religion and people’s nature. This anime is very calm; yet, it is also able to make you worry about the characters. Your heart will cry wanting to see the characters to be safe and sound, or being together. I guarantee you that you will never forget about this show.


If you have never heard anything about Spice and Wolf and you think that giving it a try would be a good idea, you should keep in mind that Spice and Wolf’s storyline is unfinished and the probability of S 3 is very low. But, don’t be upset, it shouldn’t prevent you from watching this splendid show. You can easily find a light novel on the internet, or if you are pressed for time, you can find a summary. Anyways, even being unfinished, Spice and Wolf is definitely a show, which deserves your attention.

The first time I saw Spice and Wolf, I took one look and decided it wasn't for me. After all, the main character appears to be a half-wolf half-human thing, and that's just not my thing. I like mature, romance stories, not super fantasy tales.
I couldn't have been more wrong about Spice and Wolf. Spice and Wolf is one of the most mature, well done romances I have ever seen. I've seen more human emotion out of the wolf-goddess Holo than in half of the nonsensical tsunderes I see every day. I'm not typically a fan of fantasy-esque elements in anime; yet I never feltlike the fantasy elements of Spice and Wolf detracted from the main storyline. They were always present in the storyline yet never overpowering. From the beginning It was clearly a story of Lawrence and Holo and that never changed throughout the entire series. The budding relationship of Lawrence and Holo is what drives the story throughout season 1 and 2.


Another worry I had before watching the show, was that it would be too focused on "economics". You hear "medieval economics" all the time when reading about the show. I'm not particularly interested in economics or medieval life. However I found Spice and Wolf yet again to never overplay it. The plots revolving around money schemes and the daily life of Holo/Lawrence were always interesting. I never felt overwhelmed with strange terminology, or bored. It was the perfect mix.


Spice and Wolf wasn't without its one major downside though. And that's the fact that there wasn't a season 3. Spice and Wolf is the only anime to date that I've actually thought was worth reading the source material (light novels) afterwards. I was really blown away by just how much the Light Novels read like watching the show. It was 100% worth it to continue on and finish the story from the anime. The entire experience was brilliant.


Even if the story just ended with the 2 seasons of anime though, it would be worth the watch. For fans of mature stories, of which there are so few that are well done in anime, Spice and Wolf is a MUST watch. Give it a chance if you're skeptical about its setting. It'll blow you expectations away.

I'll try and avoid going into fanboy mode because this anime turned out to be my best watch ever!
In a nutshell; A traveling merchant, after visiting a town to buy some wheat from. Happen to find out that a girl have snuck into his cart. But this is no ordinary girl. She is the wolf godess of harvest in her human form. After turn of events and bargains they accompany each other to an adventure that will take them to several cities and alot of drama!
In my opinion. Medieval times with a focus on mercantile like open market, coin values, trading and haggling just can'tgo wrong. And this anime executed it very well. Quite an original story line, using an unoriginal plot. Guy meet godess. It's done before but this is out of the ordinary. There is no 5 meter long sword or fire balls or dragons, this is quite a "real" medieval world. The church do taxes for many things and are one of the big powers. Trade guilds compete with each other etc. It's so many good things packed into one punch. And to be a short anime of 13 episodes, it really felt like i watched a 26 episode anime. I'm amazed how much they were able to put into 13 episodes!


The art is very good. People are drawn good, especially main characters and important minors. But sometimes background audience looks like paper figures which kinda ruins it but at least they are not a big bunch of black blobs. You can see that there are humans there. And when our heroes are not in a town and traveling, you have a gorgeous nature scenery and the cities and buildings are drawn very good. The world is not too bright but not to dark either, they did nice colouring on this.


Sound effects are good, i can't recall any specific but the music in S&W is amazing! The music managed to put you in the right mood and the opening theme gave the the goose bumps everytime! The ending was a nice little brake from the intense episodes.


Characters have details on them and each character is unique, how the protagonist have grey eyes and hair and a brown leather jacket and being soft hearted yet the greed of a merchant and how he must balance those and find out if he is in love her or the money. How the wolf girl have red eyes, fangs and orange/white fur and being selfish but helpful at the same time. And they also have unique personalities which was a joy. The voice actors did a great job on the characters. You get a great connection to the characters and i found them all likeable, although the male protagonist is a idiot sometimes. Which can result in facepalm moments or "Damnit! why didn't you do it?".


As for enjoyment. This was amazing! As mentioned this turned out to be one of my favorite animes and best marathon watches i've done! You have plot twists and drama on par of death note quality. The art is very well done although some background characters turn to paper. The music score in this is amazing as well! The opening makes me want to cry but it has that hidden joy in the song which prevents me from doing so. Characters are deep and great! Each one of them is unique and how they react and handle in situations is interesting. You get tied closely to the characters and you can feel them when something happens.


If medieval times is a thing for you, like games or just stories. You should definately check Spice and Wolf out. This is not a fantasy medieval world with swords, fireballs, elves and dragons. You have normal people in a harsh and realistic medieval world where the church collect the biggest taxes for helping the poor and trade leagues competing and how easy it is to be backstabbed or tricked into a trap if you are careless and how valuable it is to have a guild or friends to run when things go really bad. Trading, haggling and market value is a big part of the anime but it's done interesting. If economics is a thing for you this will be a great bonus. The relationship between the male protagonist and wolf girl is a slow one but it's there. There is alot of dialogues so if you enjoyed animes like death note, you will love this i'm sure of it!

I'll be honest: I absolutely loved Spice and Wolf. It took me a long time to buckle down and watch it, but once I did, I couldn't stop. I can't believe I skipped over it for so long. You see, I was in this romance anime phase where I would exclusively watch school-based anime. Gross, I know. I'm still a bit infatuated with school-romance anime, but that has more to do with me currently being in high school and having a soft, guilty romantic side to me. With that in mind, Spice and Wolf is my favorite romance anime yet.
When I looked at the synopsisand noticed that the main character was a furry, I teetered between watching it or forgetting all about it. I watched around four or five other animes after noticing Spice and Wolf for the first time. Each time I finished one, I'd browse MAL for another to watch, skimming over Spice and Wolf with a tortured glance. It looked boring, with the premise being a traveling merchant meeting some furry off in the wilderness. But something about it caught my eye. I can't quite explain what, though if you clicked on it in a similar manner then you've most likely felt the same. 


Once I began watching, as I said earlier, I couldn't stop. The first episode entranced me (though I always thought the ending theme was out of place). The interactions between the characters were flawless, and the dialogue felt natural. The characters were portrayed perfectly, with just the right amount of flaws to go with their otherwise story-book personalities. The main character isn't your usual romance anime main. He isn't dense as a rock with no redeeming qualities that make you question why the girl falls for him. He can be dense, but that's explained in his cautious nature. He theorizes and questions everything, looking for ways to make a profit. Because of that, he tends to fop when it comes to general interactions. 


The female lead is stunning as well. She isn't dainty or clumbsy, always tripping over her feet in a haphazard attempt to look cute. She's arrogant, witty, and mischevious as well. Yet, while lacking the general cute tropes, she still comes off as one of the cutest characters I've dealt with in a romance anime. It has to be the eyes. Or I'm a furry. I pray to God Hand that I'm not, but you never know...


Anyway, Spice and Wolf is fairly easy to get into. Some audiences may not understand everything that goes on, but it's enjoyable for just about everyone. It's one of the few series that I am willing to rewatch and pray for a new season to eventually be released. The only other time I've wanted a continuation this badly is with Natsume Yuujin-cho, and that one has met those expectations. Hopefully Spice and Wolf follows suit.

Ookami to Koushinryou(or Spice and Wolf), is one of the best romance animes out there, it has a nice rate here on MAL, and it deserves it. It has one of the best character i've ever seen (Holo) which made this anime really unique and fun to watch. 
This review if for the both seasons. 
Short review: 
-Nice plot, original, simple, beautiful. 
-Nice main characters. Especially Holo, great look, great development. 
-Enjoyable soundtrack. It fits with the action, but there is nothing memorable here .. 
-Reasonable art, the character detail is nice, although the background detail is weak. 
-Overall: 8/10. Nice lovely romance story, withsome interesting talks about economy. (i mean they really are interesting, even if you don´t understand anything about it you will get to it) 


Now more detailed, 


Story: 8/10. This is a fantasy anime, and in fact it has it. But only in our main character, Holo. She is a wolf that can be in human form if she wants to. She is some kind of god of wheat (at that time, wheat was really important for civilization). The story takes place at 600 DC,  a time were being merchant was a comun job. The other main character, Lawrence Craft is one of them. When all of a sudden, Holo appears in front of him, they start a journey together, helping each other with the problems that they are going to face. 


I found no plot holes, and all the things related to economy are really well explained so i belive even if you don´t understand much about it, don´t worry i didn´t understand either but this anime taught me a lot of things about it :) 



As i said, the plot is really simple, nothing deep. Yet for being so simple it gets nice. At least i felt that way. 


Art: 7/10. Well  only the characters look nice, not the best art but at least nice design. They are well shaped, with bright colours that fits with the anime. The only bad problem may be the background, it looks pretty bad sometimes.  


Sound: 8/10. Pretty much a normal sound, makes the romance moments intense, the rest is meh we can accept it well. The music fits better with the time when the action takes place. I mean the music has the same style as the music of that time. So it gives a nice enviroment. The openings are beautiful and in my opinion, they fit well with Holo's feelings and with the romance between our main characters. 


Character: 9/10. We only have 2 characters with development. Holo takes the first place, while Lawrence gets behind, he does not have much development as Holo had but still it is a nice one. 

Throughout the anime, we get to know how Holo feels about everything, i mean they explore pretty well this character which for being so cute and so funny gets super interesting to see her development. She is a mixed of emotions and feelings. Or she is fragile, or she is strong. Plus she is wise and teach a lot of things about the world to Lawrence, while he teaches things about humans as well to Holo(because she didn´t had much contact with humans). On top of that, the slow progressive romance between them both makes the anime pretty cute and also we can see a excelent development in their relationship, which is just lovely. Personaly, i loved that aspect. 


Enjoyment: 9/10. We can divide this anime into mini arcs. Every arc takes place in one city, and there is always a problem to solve. And between those arcs or even in the middle, we have my favorite part, the development. It is just amazing the way that they talk to each other. We get to know everything about them both, and it is just amazing. I felt something that i've never had felt before, so this anime for me became memorable ! Their dialogues are at the same time intense, cute, dramatic, or simply all of that together. 


Overall this show is a lovely show with a cute main character and i belive for who likes romance, this is one that you need to check out.

After hearing so much about "Spice and Wolf" and how many people consider it one of the best anime around, I finally sat down to watch the first season. Having done so, I must say that I am surprised just how enthusiastic some reviews of this show have been. Personally, I thought this show was...good. Just that. A good show to casually watch and enjoy, but hardly a show that would stick out to me among many others. 
Here are a few reasons why I did like the show...and a few reasons why I wouldn't rank it as highly as some other people have done:
-The show is often praised for its unique story concept, fusing a bit of romance with a plot about medieval economics...however, I thought it was a bit of a shame that the economic aspects of the show, which are such a central aspect, were primarily aspects that ONLY apply to economics in medieval times, thus being of little relevance or interest to a modern viewer, unless someone is specifically interested in history for history's sake. In comparison, another anime about medieval economics, Maoyuu Maou Yuusha, featured general economic issues about how to build a state or an economy that are still relevant today, which made the plot a lot more interesting in my opinion.


- The character of Holo, a transforming wolf deity, is certainly unique...however, it is therefore a bit disappointing that her personality is often reduced to that of a generic tsundere character. That's often fun and cute and all, but it doesn't quite fit the idea of an ancient wise godess. Maybe that's why she constantly has to remind the audience explicitely that she is indeed the wise wolf Holo. Still, despite her tsundere mood swings, her intelligence and wolf-abilities make her a fairly interesting character.


- The relationship dynamic between Holo and Lawrence is thankfully always interesting and pleasant to watch...but, on a negative note, it is one example of how this show does not transcend many other typical romance anime. The characters and the relationship is nice...but not that unique. Similar relationships with similar back-and-forth dialogue can be found in several other anime. Still, it's never annoying or boring to watch, thus making it still a good experience.


- The medieval setting and the soundtrack are certainly worth a watch...even if the animation is fairly average.



All in all, I think hardly anybody who watches Spice and Wolf would be disappointed with it. It's a good show and 13 enjoyable episodes fly by fast. It's just that, out of a bunch of several other "good" anime, I would know no reason why it should be considered to stand out in any significant way. Many other anime seem to be just as decent as this one. Good, but not spectacular.

Horo is the Sage Wolf. Her normal form is that of a Giant Wolf, but she can alter her form into an auburn haired girl with ears and a tail. She has looked after the grain fields of a village for thousands of years. But now, she has a wish. She wants to go home. To the north.  To do this, she recruits the help of friendly merchant Lawrence, who's dream is to open his own shop, by forcefully stealing way into his cart. her soul inhabits the grain that Lawrence bought at this village. As payment for taking her North, she offers tohelp Lawrence make enough money to open his own shop.The two begin a journey to the north, along which Lawrence attempts to make money using his trade. Together, the two travel from town to town meeting varieties of people, becoming closer to one and other, and running into a kind of trouble different from the usual anime conflict. Financial trouble. This anime has little to do with violence and fighting for friendship. Instead the conflict is based on any financial trouble Lawrence and Horo encounter, from the change in the value of coin, to buying goods that are actually worthless. This anime is more about the journey than the destination, and it is an incredible journey. 


DON'T DISMISS IT YET! This anime is nowhere near as boring as what i just said sounds. This is one of the few intellectual anime that you will really ever find. Despite there being a wolf, there is next to no violence in this anime. Instead, it is replaced with Horo's adorable way of talking and her sharp wit. The two constantly compete with one and other in a love hate relationship. It is amazing to watch the way these two characters interact with one and other.


I watched this anime while i was taking an economics class, and I swear i got an A because of it. The thoughts and concepts this anime portray are so accurate that the creators deserve an ovation for properly explaining and implementing such complex concepts ideas into a anime without being boring. Kudos to you guys and congrats on a job well done.

This anime has a gripping story, great characters, and a fantasy world that isn't like your average fantasy world with magic  and fantasy species, in fact its a lot like our medieval world with one exception, which is in fact our main heroine, Holo. 
   Actually, Holo is one of the main reasons why i love this anime so much, shes sly and smug, but also quirky and sometimes blissful. She's extremely intelligent and a quick-learner, but is often prone to child-like attitudes, and awe-struck wonder to some of the simplest things. 
   Holo is one ofthe reasons why this anime stands so high for me. Don't get me wrong Kraft Lawrence is an amazing character as well and often his veteran merchant-like attitude offsets perfectly with Holo's more childlike demenor, its just that Holo is such an unpredictable character that you never know when she might pull a rabbit out of her hat, or use her silver tongue to talk herself out of purgatory. Holo seems to be able to make even the most boring trip from one town to the next out to be an exciting adventure. As for the world it does a great job of immersing you in it as well as giving you both background and information so that you feel like you understand the intricacies of the world. Even the opening to the anime by Natsumi Kiyoura is such a good song that it simply send shivers down my spine when i listen to it. \n
   However I don't necessarily feel like this is an anime for everyone. As I describe it, its "half anime, half economics" and often comes off as being a bit slow and having little in the way of action. The anime is heavy in dialogue and if you watch anime in the original Japanese with English subtitles like I do, it also means a lot of reading.  \n
   Still, the characters, the story, and the atmosphere all come together so perfectly that it is a great master piece in my book. That is why it is my 2nd favorite anime series of all time.\n
(PS: I listened to Tabi no Tochuu (the Opening from the anime) while I wrote this review)\n

Spice and Wolf represents a very interesting and unique outlook on relationships. It's not a surprise however that an anime expressed through use of a time period in which people still pray to pagan Gods could appear to be boring to some watchers. As an individual who enjoys animes that can transport oneself to an intense space battle or see characters face immense challenges with their supernatural powers I was a bit skeptical taking this slice-of-life journey about a traveling merchant and a wolf girl. Obviously I was overjoyed to find this masterful gem.
Although I can imagine most watchers believing Spice and Wolf being onlyabout their relationship growing while their wealth of money and experience grow as well. I would not argue with this thought but I would have to say that it is much more than that. Kraft Lawrence, our main character and expert merchant, is kind-hearted individual who doesn't mind getting his hands a little dirty in the name of business. In fact he even goes as far to tell Holo the Wise Sage Wolf, his companion, that all he thinks about is his business and dream to own his own shop. Watchers learn much about the ways of negotiating, bartering, and trading as well as techniques that border on absolute cunning. What makes Spice and Wolf unique is that the more we learn about merchant trading the more we see that relationships are the same. The bond between Holo and Lawrence perfectly illustrates the lessons in love and trading. With each town they travel to they experience different hardship that is linked not only in trading but in romance. Throughout their journeys we see actions of greed, selfishness, and risk applied to both of Lawrence's relationships: trading and Holo. This is clearly represented through their long dialogue and without understanding the connection between the two can leave watchers confused and bored. Overall, Spice and Wolf's story line is simple but full of emotion that makes you longing for more.


The art work is basic for being produced in 2008 but it might have been on purpose to further represent the older time that the story takes place. Either way it doesn't affect the watchability of the anime. 


I lose complete interest in an anime when the personality of a character changes throughout the story, especially when the characters are older. Character growth is extremely important to any good story. What did the character learn? How have they grown to meet the various challenges they faced? Becoming more courageous or becoming bolder are characteristics that can change easily through various events but personalities stay the same - it's who we are. In Spice and Wolf we see cleverly how growth changes how one makes decisions and expertly how their personalities remain true despite their many challenges. Perhaps one of the best reasons for selecting a (10) is the fact that the characters we love at the beginning, are the same characters we love in the end. 


I leave you with a simple conclusion - if you are one that watches anime purely for how it looks then this anime is most likely not for you. But if you enjoy listening to the several lessons that great animes contain then Spice and Wolf is a great place to look. The love is subtle and yet strong. If I could add anything to the wonderful work it would be to have seen a more  affectionate Lawrence. Although he clearly develops a strong bond with Holo that rivals even his obsession with his trade it could have been more clearly displayed to watchers waiting eagerly for that special moment.

This show shocked me with how much I loved it. There aren't many that do but when you find them you can't help but treasure every minute of it. The story sounds kind of boring from reading the synopsis and the heavy use of currency exchange rates and bartering would turn off anyone who doesn't watch bloomberg, but somehow it all works here. Watching Holo and Lawrence traveling and getting to know each other and the world they live in is a joy. Their journey playing out as this strange romance with people that seem to have no chance at love and sticking together anyway.This is one of those must see shows that come around so rarely.

What happens to the gods when people stop believing in them? Do they disappear, or simply go back home? While finding a person you love, is "forever" a simple word?
This is, simply, a story about a merchant travelling and selling goods, trying to get by the best way possible, with a little fantasy put in as his companion is a pagan goddess, trying to get home. The story is simple, at the same time deep and complex, it relaxes you while making you think. Being composed almost completely out of dialogue, it never becomes repetitive or boring.
People, nature, rural buildings appearing around them while travellingare all done nicely. It creates a feeling as if you were there too, sitting in the cart listening Lawrence and Horo bicker. The only thing I didn't like is that the characters  were sometimes looking a little stiff.


Sound is perfectly composed with the nature of the anime. Voice actors, background music and the opening song were completely adapted to the nature of the anime, never sounding sudden or weird. The ending song makes me happy :)


The relationship between the two main characters is progressive and subtle. From complete strangers, bickering partners then friends, it is completely natural that it would eventually turn into love.

Listening to their conversation would be similar to imagining a ball flying from one to another end during a tennis match. There is passing, bluffing or playing cute, but, unlike many other couples, everything's completely honest and said out loud. Both of the characters say everything that's on their mind, be it embarrassing or maybe a little teasing.


Lawrence is a successful merchant, charismatic and smart. Still, he would be far from perfect. As every human being, he makes stupid mistakes and gets angry, despite being a "nice guy". Being much more mature than most anime mains, in the eyes of Horo, he's still just an innocent, little boy.


Horo is a beautiful wolf pagan deity. She is much more cunning then Lawrence, she doesn't miss saying that to him, too. Despite being hundreds of centuries old, she still likes playing around, sometimes greeedy like a little child. Though, behind a playful smile, hides a past of centuries of loneliness, which comes out only in her most vulnerable times, when she's not strong enough to hide it.


It is funny, how most of the time the dominant role's being switched back and forth between the two of them. Being older and wiser, Horo often regards Lawrence as a little boy who just started learning about the world. At the same time, when she starts looking for food or is just being weak, Lawrence acts with her as if with a child.


Historical anime. If it's not unusual beasts and fantasy creatures, or knights, swords and fighting, then it must be a samurai story or at least an action with magic. It's nice to see anime that breaks out of a cliche at so many places.

Relationship is natural and warm, and the people feel alive.


Being one of my all-time favorites, and probably will always be, I enjoyed this anime a lot. :)

I couldn't pass over this anime to save my life. Being a big fan of Code Geass to see Jun and Ami as the main roles had me much excited to check out the voice acting in this one. I've also read the manga and loved it enough to bother going over the story again in the anime adaptation, you can pretty much tell how my review is going to be.
Story - This anime takes place in a sort of medieval universe. Lawrence is a traveling merchant and dreams of opening his own shop in a town where he can settle down and have theprivileges granted from staying in one location to trade, such as finding a wife and having close friends. Being more specific with this anime's universe, religion is universally recognized as the highest power, beside gold and silver coins. Both of which are more highly regardless than the god of grain harvest Horo. Horo is a wolf but takes a human form and meets Lawrence. He makes a promise with Horo to take her up to the north forest in his travels of trade as he does so he learns about the many powers Horo has and how he can use them to benefit his trade. It seems more money is spent on keeping Horo content and happy than she helps make. Spending it on trivial goods as apples, clothes, and alcoholic drinks.


Basically the plot is about Lawrence and Horo dealing with many business opportunities, some being very perilous, and there are points where it feels as all is lost for Lawrence.


It might sound either very dull or enjoyable, I warn you there is a ton of information to process and viewers will not understand why anyone is doing anything unless giving it their full attention. You must have a base understanding of economics. Even if you don't it's still watchable but it won't be as interesting as learning every side of the story. It's better to pick up everything as it goes on or you might not be able to find what you need by going back.


9 - Yes there is a romance story, but we all know where that's going.


Art - The art was fantastic and captures the medieval universe very well. The clothing, people, villages, landscape, very much fit the archetype of the middle ages.


8 - Beautiful, much to stare at as they talk about business matters.


Sound - Goodness did I enjoy the voice acting in this one. The long dialogue was done professionally. The BGM was very enjoyable, there was a sort of cheery flute music that I favored. The OP doesn't sink it at first, but as you keep hearing it, you find it to be a soothing and rather beautiful song. The ED I enjoyed a slight more, the accents for the English lyrics, I will never be able to emulate. It's a cute song really, something out of a children play. Expect some great howling and voice acting.


8 - long explanations, no problem.


Character - Being about a traveling merchant Lawrence never gets to spend much time with anyone in the span of the anime. Besides Horo, all the other characters are in it for their respective arcs and never feel as important as Horo or Lawrence. What's important is that they focused on the two characters that matter the most. You learn a lot about both and learn to love them both.


8 - To describe it, I would compare it to a very small but delicious plate of high class cooking. You wanted more but at the same time fear that it might spoil the Horo/Lawrence combo.


Enjoyment - While never having to pay attention to the subtitles in a long time, i found every bit of business spiel interesting and enjoyable. I would have never been able to write a story such as this one involving so much about trade and economics, the falling and rising of prices, dealing, contracts, companies, scams, etc.


In the end you get your money's worth of story and content, to top it all off you have a very attractive and skillful wolf God in the mix.


9 - Very much satisfied thank you. I anticipate the second season!


Overall - Prepare to be entertained, in the smart way. Never has trading been so tense and interesting.


So stop what you're doing, put that down, and watch this.


I give it a deserving 9!

STORY (8/10)
The story of spice and wolf is overly simplistic, but don’t get me wrong, simple things can be the best things. Ookami to Koushinryou is a story about Lawrence, a traveling merchant and Holo, a wolf deity. While economics do play a part in spice and wolf, you shouldn’t let it stop you if you don’t like the subject. The economics are really interesting in the series, you can see how Lawrence do his trades and earn his money, but obviously the story isn’t only about this. On a personal point I think it’s the characters that make this series original and good.
SOUND (8/10)
Ilove spice and wolf ost’s, the opening is great, it fits so well with the anime, even the ending is good (even if it’s ‘’engrish’’). I really loved Holo and Lawrence voices, they fit perfectly. The background ost’s really add a good atmosphere in the anime, they are unique, it’s the kind of ost that I enjoy listening while doing other things.


CHARACTERS (9/10)

This is by far the best part of spice and wolf. The characters are so unique. Holo is an awesome character, her personality is well made and she’s an original character, she’s not your main tsundere girl you will see in every anime. Lawrence is a good character too, this guy doesn’t know how to talk to a girl which can be funny sometimes, how he doesn’t understand how Holo thinks, and he’s a cool merchant, what else can I say? The relationship between our two main characters are something that I really enjoyed, there’s always a ‘’tease and tease back’’ when they talk together. It’s really enjoyable and they are the type of characters you will eventually care for as the story goes.


ENJOYMENT (8/10)

If you’re someone like me who really enjoys when characters are well made and are not left undeveloped you will definitely enjoy everything about spice and wolf. As a light novel reader I think the season one was really well adapted, they did not leave weird plot holes that they could have done by skipping light novels things, which is really enjoyable. I would definitely re-watch spice and wolf in a year or two. I can’t, but suggest anyone who loves spice and wolf to read the novels, they are awesome. Spice and Wolf as surely climb to my top five favorite series of all time


OVERALL: 8/10, would recommend


TL:DR: Story is great, characters are awesome, memorable series, if you like spice and wolf I suggest that you read the novel to continue this awesome adventure!

If you've seen any of the other media associated with this anime, you probably think you know what it's about. Cute wolf girls, lots of fan service, medieval action, etc. It is with no small amount of surprise that I can report that this show is not at all what it appears to be on the surface. I believe that I'd go so faras to call it truly unique--at least, I've never encountered another anime (or really, television show period) that's comparable. Yes, it draws you in with the furry manic pixie dream girl element, but two episodes in it reveals its true intentions: Spice & Wolf is not about mindless, hyperactive cuteness and adventure. At the risk of sounding off-putting, it's equal parts Renaissance-era Wall Street and Linklateresque talky romance. Let's approach these two halves one at a time.


Anime fans are used to action. Even the rom-com and every-day life drama anime equivalents typically have action sequences. Consider the mindlessly cute and mostly harmless Fruits Basket--sure, the kung-fu is mostly used for comedic effect and nothing is really at stake, but that doesn't stop these action sequences from being choreographed carefully (well, within the context of the show) and from being absorbing at a character level. There are exceptions to this generalization, but even if there's no strict action there still tend to be sequences of increased hyperactivity that pass for action--characters bouncing around the frame and super-deforming to ramp up the emotion, drama, or absurdity of a sequence are very common, as are moments of un-explainable magical realism or characters showing off previously unseen skills to liven up the on-screen happenings a bit.


While Spice & Wolf doesn't break completely from the above conventions (obviously--there's a wolf-girl, after all!), it does so more drastically than any other anime I've seen, with the possible exception of Paradise Kiss. The key difference between the two is that Paradise Kiss built tension by relying on coming-of-age storytelling elements and teenage angst. Spice & Wolf is concerned with economics and trade. And I'm not saying that it's concerned with economics and trade in the same way that Hikaru no Go is concerned with Go. There is very little effort to hold the viewers' hand or to make the tension of the central machinations 'more exciting.' Spice & Wolf's plot twists revolve around market crashes, unexpected fees, and the ebb & flow of supply and demand. Its characters talk at great length and (and so far as I can tell) display great knowledge about market influences, financial risk assessment, credit poisoning, etc. Occasionally (particularly in the first season), surprise violence pushes the plot forward, but more frequently it's the hazards of being a traveling merchant in a volatile market that supplies the series' tension, at least on the plot-arc level. 


It's not for everyone. Some are going to find it incomprehensible. I actually had to rewind and pause frequently while watching the subtitled version to fully understand what was happening in some scenes (and some moments are still beyond me), and I was pleasantly surprised to realize that the characters were 'coming' to conclusions more quickly than I was--which almost never happens in anime. Anime is fully capable of being heady and difficult--though frequently when it is challenging your intelligence it's doing so from a post-modern/avant-garde/metaphorical position. Spice & Wolf instead challenges your logic and your intuition. When its characters sit down to discuss business, you realize that they are playing a very advanced game of chess, or perhaps poker, with one another. They are gambling, and the stakes are high, and if you're not as in-tune with their dealings as they are, you will get left behind. I thought it was actually sort of exhilarating. Frustrating, yes, but challenging and stimulating. Of course, I suspect that this aspect of the show won't hold up as well on repeat viewings--which is where the romance comes into play, and where the writers really, really deserve credit.


The story gets its start when Holo, a wolf goddess who influences wheat yields for a small southern town, sneaks onto a travelling merchant's cart on his way out of town. The townsfolk, through their own ingenuity, no longer require her supernatural intervention, and she is tired of being alone and unneeded. She wants to journey north, to her place of origin, and reunite with entities she has not seen in centuries, and has largely forgotten. The series hints (or maybe I'm reading into it way too deeply) that her hugely extended lifespan may be coming to its drawn-out conclusion--she seems to suffer physically from a weak constitution, and mentally from years of regret and a desire to do things over again. The merchant she imposes herself upon is Lawrence, and he is truly a breath of fresh air, insofar as male leads in anime are concerned. He's got a head of grey hair and has already been through his 'coming-of-age' story. Lawrence has learned how to be an adult and has been one for some time. He's set in his ways, wise, and sure of himself. He does have some weaknesses, particularly for pretty women and for gold, but he knows what he wants in life, and is already working toward it when he discovers the very naked Holo in the back of his cart.


Let me quantify 'very naked' here. Holo is shown nude frequently throughout the series--as a wolf goddess, the only reason she really wears clothes at all are to hide her ears and tail from prying eyes when in her 'human' form. This sounds like a weak attempt to defend the nudity, but it helps that Holo's nudity is rarely sexualized, thanks to her Barbie doll anatomy--by which I mean not only in the lack of explicitly drawn detail (contrast this to the frequently disgusting nude fan service in a show like Elfen Lied), but in her unrealistic features (her conical breasts). She does know that she's attractive and uses her sex appeal to her advantage, but in another rare turn for anime, she manages to do so while being clothed head to foot. (Indeed, when in public, she looks almost like a nun, albeit a stylish one.)


Anyways, Lawrence, in awe of her power, agrees to aid her in her journey north. Along the way they become business partners after Holo demonstrates uncanny business sense and intuition, and they quickly thereafter become fast friends. They consistently and amusingly banter with one another, and their teasing and flirting (sometimes gentle, sometimes not) is a pleasure to behold. They both relish wit and wordplay, yet both seem afraid of their emotions, and occasionally wound each other deeply. By the time the second season starts, we realize that Holo may love Lawrence in ways that he either does not reciprocate or is afraid of returning, and Holo is afraid of the emotional harm she'll do to herself if she allows herself to love a mortal, whose lifespan is but the blink of an eye, compared to hers. It's a well-worn idea in fiction (and in myth), but is here spiced up considerably by their complex relationship that balances business and flirtatious friendship with Holo's need to go home and Lawrence's dreams of owning his own storefront in a large city. They cannot travel together for forever, no matter how much they enjoy one another's company. The two come to the conclusion that it may take in excess of a year to find Holo's home-this is presumably not a problem for Holo, but a year is a long time for Lawrence. Lawrence can only put his life on hold for her for so long, and when Holo realizes this fact, she begins to consider leaving him early and letting him move on with his life.


Viewers conditioned to expect certain things from romantic relationships in anime might be frustrated. (Typical YouTube comment: 'I would sell my family just to see Holo and Lawrence kiss!') Both strive to keep the heat between them low, but both eventually become possessive of one another, and commonly-explored themes like jealousy and self-sacrifice are given time in the limelight, though in ways viewers may not be used to seeing. In a sense watching the relationship between the two grow can be maddening--the writers treat the romance on a slightly cool and reserved level (outside of Holo's seemingly playful attempts to seduce Lawrence), and so much depends on what the viewers think of the characters themselves. It'd be easy to just call Holo a manipulative tease and Lawrence a greedy idiot and just move onto another anime with more 'satisfactory' character development. In fact, it almost seems like the writers are trying to do this on purpose--as if they were weeding their audience. Viewers that become truly invested in Holo and Lawrence will be physically pained when the two genuinely fight--others will just shrug and say that they don't get it. 


The ending will please even fewer people. The ultimate destination is not reached, with the writers opting for an emotional climax instead--albeit it a hugely understated one that relies on a close, almost literary reading of the characters and an important development in the penultimate episode to get anything out of. It will please those who admire restraint, but people who want definite conclusions will either be itching for a third season or will just be turned off completely. Truthfully, I would not mind seeing a third season myself, and since the anime is based on a still ongoing series of novels and/or manga, there is more than enough material to justify another season. Still, it's a finely honed ending to a finely honed series that has subverted expectations throughout. I realize that I haven't yet written about the art or the music (both fine, but neither amazing), but let's leave it at this: Spice & Wolf is a series that boasts incredibly well-developed characters, fantastic writing, and a unique sensibility with regards to conflict and resolution. It trades in action for talkiness, and ease of appreciation for real challenge. Its greatest flaws (the mercantile plot, the tricky romantic angle) are also its strongest attributes. It's not for everyone, but you won't know if it's not for you until you give it a try. Or if you possess greater respect for my reviews than I do, myself. Lol.

Spice and Wolf is a perfect example where I loved a series despite not grasping the telling of the tale of this fantasy, this historical fiction, and a simple story of growth and bond. I loved most of the first season. It's fair to say that I'm not in the minority about not understanding the economical side of the story. I'd go as far as saying that I expect 80% of the viewers were too young or not sharp enough to get the gist at first viewing. Despite not much happening in the first season, you cannot know for sure that somethingwill not happen at some point. If this anime were a Japanese novel, it'd be stunning. I'd probably not be able to lay my hands on that imaginary book, and I'd not even be aware of it. Big thanks to the anime community for keeping on producing art that is risky, outlandish, solemn, daring, thoughtful, eager, wholesome, fantastic, and in the case of Spice and Wolf, humble and unpretentious.


  The animation is gorgeous. Most animes, especially long running ones, tend to lower the absolute best bar of the background, so as to blend in the characters and the decor, landscape and the background.  There's also the budget and the schedule to think of. Spice and Wolf foolhardily gives us some gorgeous and magical drawings of  the scenery and boldly differs the animated characters from the world. This, is not a problem, as there is no gamble that paid off, since I'm sure the animators knew what they were doing. Considering that I've never seen such rendering in any other anime I can think of, I wonder why this is so. The standards of animation has followed the trajectory of any medium where drawing is involved - anime, manga, comics. These last few years have been a golden age for anime and I wish - en passant - that along with us, the hardworking animators would profit from it as much as us viewers do.


  The strong points in favor of the high score eclipses the lapses in Spice and Wolf but we do feel the errors' pull. Humor is surprisingly near inexistent in most of the 13 episodes I've watched. The 'acting' of Lawrence in particular, is lacking in subtle and varied terms. This seems to be a direct result of the yoyoing playful but repetitive bond between Holo and Lawrence. Holo is the playful character and it's good that she doesn't joke really, but taunts and teases, but often with a punctuality coated with girlish charm. The routine that develops is that Holo keeps on yanking the chain of Lawrence and we expect Lawrence to retort but his reactions are the shrugs of a man prematurely old and fully knowing of his situation, and accepting it with stoic regularity.


  I've forgotten most of the males' names and remember Nora Arendt's because the former are so many and interchangeable while women are at a premium in Spice and Wolf. The drawing style of the anime is not kiddy at all and Nora is the one that benefits most from it. I was quickly concerned about her well-being, and I don't know for sure who she is exactly. She seems shy, devout, humble, timid but trusting and fearless and loving towards her animals. She is important in providing a rival of sorts for Holo. Or at least, that's what they want you to believe. Talking about Spice and Wolf is rather difficult and I've done my best, and exceptionally, I count this review to be more writing than talking. After reading many reviews and seeing the awsome rates people gave to this anime, i had pretty high expectations, and although it was a good show it wasn't as good as i though it would be. 
Story:
I found the story very original because it is focused on economy and how is a merchant life in medieval times. But i felt that this topic was featured in the series to only been understand by people how knows about economy.  The strategies used are so complexly explained that you have to re-watch many times these scenes to actually understand what are they going to do. 
Iimagine that probably most viewers won't be masters of economic studies, so that might hold up you a little bit in the storyline.


Realism:

This anime introduces a medieval atmosphere that i have never seen in any other anime so far. Most anime that are located in the middle ages mix magic and spells that take out any realism of the series (such as Zero no tsukaima, for example). Spice and wolf have a totally different feeling: Everything look so real and accurated to the time. The clothes, buildings, social scale, economy, transport, the power of church, everything.


Sound:

The soundtrack fits perfectly with all the atmosphere, the right instruments are used and that really helps to the enjoyment of the series. The opening is gorgeus, i didn't skip it a single time, and after listening to it many time i realised that apart from the female voice, in the chorus, there was a male voice behind; and that made me love even more the song.

The ending song isn't appealing for me but the pictures that are shown in the ending looks really cute.


Characters:

In my opinion if it wasn't for Horo, the whole cast would be boring and forgettable. The only one that stands out is her: She's sassy, smart and funny. The other characters, including the main one, are just generic.

Something that pissed me off is how Chloe's character is managed trough the anime. You see all this secondary characters which you know that won't appear more than 2 chapters in the series and won't be very important; but Chloe looks like she's going to do something big in the series. After many episodes without seen Chloe, she appears in one envolved in a big problem with a company. I though: "Oh, i knew she was gonna be important" but, no! She´s just left to the side and what could became a perfect villain becomes another forgettable character. I would wanted to watch her confronting Lawrence face to face.


Art:

The art in general is good but i found some scenes were the backgrounds are static and while Horo and Lawrence are walking, the rest of the people are in a certain position without moving and that feels weird. The characters could have had more realistic features to complete the hole atmosphere, but is was fine anyway.


To end up my opinion, i think that the end was too opened. I know there is another season but sometimes is better to round a little bit everything to give a nicer feeling.
